awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Black-Box Evaluation of Cryptographic Entropy at Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to generate random numbers -- to flip coins -- is crucial for many computing tasks, from Monte Carlo simulation to secure communications.   The theory of building such subsystems to generate random numbers is well understood, but the gap between theory and practice is surprisingly wide.  As built today, these subsystems are opaque and fragile.  Flaws in these subsystems can compromise the security of millions of Internet hosts.

This project will develop black-box techniques for finding entropy failures at Internet scale related to randomness.  These techniques, which build on programming languages, operating systems, networking, security, and cryptography, will then be applied to perform a systematic, ongoing census of the state of random number generation vulnerabilities.  Through this census, the project can analyze the "longtail" of deployed networked systems rather than a handful chosen a priori.

The project will develop and disseminate defensive analysis tools that will help programmers debug and correct entropy problems in their code before they ship it.  It will produce cryptographic countermeasures and entropy-gathering subsystems that provide better security guarantees than existing systems, reducing the impact of those entropy failures that do slip through.

The result will be a better understanding of entropy and more trustworthy systems, today and in the future.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced the computer science community’s understanding of the security of cryptographic protocols used for Internet communication, and it contributed to major improvements to the way these protocols are deployed and used in practice, leading to better security for billions of people.

Intellectual Merit: Research under the project introduced new techniques for understanding and improving the security of cryptographic implementations by using large-scale empirical data about Internet hosts. Highlights include the discovery and/or analysis of three major vulnerabilities in the TLS protocol: the FREAK, Logjam, and DROWN attacks. Each of these vulnerabilities stemmed from a different aspect of 1990s-era U.S. policies that restricted the strength of cryptography that could be exported from the country. Although these restrictions were lifted in the early 2000s, remnants in the design of TLS threatened the security of millions of websites in the mid-2010s. Other studies under the project discovered problems and suggested stronger defenses for email delivery, network middleboxes, FTP servers, and HTTPS deployments on CDNs. The project resulted in the publication of 23 papers and dissertations, including one Best Paper Award winner and one recipient of the IRTF Applied Networking Research Prize.

Broader Impacts: Three PhD students who participated in the project completed their degrees, and two received offers for tenure-track faculty positions. Five undergraduates who participated in the work went on to pursue PhDs in computer science. Techniques developed under the project led to the founding of a startup company, Censys, Inc., which is commercializing the technology to help enterprises better secure their networks and devices. Vulnerabilities discovered under this project led to changes in the operation of all major web browser and web server software, significant revisions to the TLS protocol, changes in the operations of major CDNs, the introduction of new features and protocols for protecting email, and changes to the operations of HTTPS certificate authorities. The result is an Internet that is safer for users worldwide.
